quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 2)
quiz.subtitle: Newton's First Law and Free Body Diagrams (10 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Action-reaction pairs in FBDs:
options: Both appear on the same FBD
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law: action-reaction pairs act on different objects, so they never appear on the same FBD.

questions.question: For a hanging object, tension equals weight when:
options: Object is at rest or constant velocity

questions.question: If a box is subjected to a $10\text{ N}$ force acting East and a $6\text{ N}$ force acting West, what is the net force?
Which of the following should NEVER be included as a separate, independent arrow on a Free Body Diagram?
questions.explanation: FBD shows only actual forces acting ON the object. Net force is the result, not a separate force.

questions.question: Kinetic friction always acts in which direction?
options: The same direction as the object's velocity.
Opposite to the direction of sliding relative to the surface.
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction opposes relative motion between surfaces, so it acts opposite to sliding direction.

questions.question: Every object near the Earth's surface experiences gravity. In which direction should the Weight ($F_g$) vector always point?
questions.explanation: Weight is force due to gravity, always directed downward toward Earth's center.

questions.question: Newton's First Law of Motion is also commonly referred to as the:
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law describes inertia: objects resist changes in their state of motion.

questions.question: What is the natural tendency of an object regarding its state of motion?
options: To resist changes in its state of motion.
To accelerate in the direction of the largest force.
To always follow a curved path.
questions.explanation: Inertia is the tendency of objects to resist changes in their velocity.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions must be met for an object to be in equilibrium?
options: The object must be at rest.
The velocity must be increasing at a constant rate.
The net force acting on the object must be zero.
Only one force can be acting on the object.

questions.question: A car is traveling due North at a constant speed of $100\text{ km/h}$ on a straight highway. What is the net force acting on the car?
options: Directed due South to counter friction.
Equal to the weight of the car.
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means zero acceleration, so $F_{net} = ma = 0$.
